review.title: Combining Multiple Feature Extraction Techniques for Handwritten Devnagari Character Recognition
review.abstract: In this paper we present an OCR for Handwritten Devnagari Characters. Basic symbols are recognized by neural classifier. We have used four feature extraction techniques namely, intersection, shadow feature, chain code histogram and straight line fitting features. Shadow features are computed globally for character image while intersection features, chain code histogram features and line fitting features are computed by dividing the character image into different segments. Weighted majority voting technique is used for combining the classification decision obtained from four Multi Layer Perceptron(MLP) based classifier. On experimentation with a dataset of 4900 samples the overall recognition rate observed is 92.80% as we considered top five choices results. This method is compared with other recent methods for Handwritten Devnagari Character Recognition and it has been observed that this approach has better success rate than other methods.

sections.text: The aim of this algorithm is to distinguish between image pixels that belong to the text and those that belong to the background. The algorithm mentioned below is applied to grayscale images: -a) Take the threshold at 128 (mean from 0 to 255).b) Take all pixels with grayscale value above 128 as the background and all pixels with value below 128 as the foreground.c) Find the mean grayscale values of the background pixels and foreground pixel.d) Find the mean of both averages and make this the new threshold.e) Go back to step (b) and continue this process of refining the threshold until the threshold changes from one iteration to the next below 2%.

sections.text: The ultimate goal of pattern recognition is to combine the best possible classification performance to achieve an accurate result, which has traditionally led to the development of different classification schemes for each pattern recognition problem to solve. The result of an experimental evaluation of the different designs would then be the basis for selecting one of the classification selections as the definitive solution to the problem. It had been observed in such design studies that although one of the designs would provide the best performance of the selected classification schemes, the sets of patterns would be misclassified, which would not necessarily overlap by the different classifiers, suggesting that different classification designs would provide potentially complementary information about the pattern to be classified, which could be used to improve the performance of the selected classifier.
